{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox road |country=GBR |type=A |route=158 | map=[[File:A158 road map.png|200px]]|map_custom=yes|map_notes=Click map to enlarge |length_mi=41 |direction_a= |terminus_a = Lincoln |direction_b= |terminus_b = Skegness |junction = {{ukroadsmall-svg|46}}

{{ukroadsmall|157}}

{{ukroadsmall-svg|52}} |destinations = }} The '''A158''' road is a major tourist route that heads from [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]] in the west to [[Skegness]] on the east coast. The road is located entirely in the [[county]] of [[Lincolnshire]] and is [[single carriageway]] for almost its entirety. The road is approximately {{convert|41|mi|km}} long. The road gets quite congested with holiday traffic during the summer. ==Lincoln to Horncastle== [[File:The road to Lincoln - geograph.org.uk - 1152235.jpg|thumb|140px|left|Approach to Lincoln at North Greetwell]] The road begins outside Lincoln as part of the by-pass at the [[A46 road|A46]] {{nowrap|({{coord|53.2542|-0.5130|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A158 road (western end)}}).}} roundabout with ''Nettleham Road'' ([[B1182 road|B1182]]). The road does not enter the borough of Lincoln, and begins in the parish of [[Nettleham]] in [[West Lindsey]]. Before the Lincoln Bypass was built (in stages) in the mid-1980s, the A158 historically went along ''Wragby Road'' (now the A15). Even earlier the A158 followed the northern end of ''Canwick Road'', the former B1188, over Pelham Bridge since its opening in 1958, and along ''South Park Avenue'' which was also built in 1958, to meet the former A46 at [[St. Catherines, Lincoln|St Catherine's]]. This was parallel to the former western section B1190. The A15 at the time followed the west of Lincoln town centre, then along ''Silver Street''. It heads south-east for {{convert|1|mi}} before reaching a roundabout where the [[A15 road (Great Britain)|A15]] joins from the centre of Lincoln. From here the route heads north-east [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2668659 through] the village of [[North Greetwell]] along a former [[Roman road]], where it is the parish boundary between [[Nettleham]] to the north and [[Greetwell, West Lindsey|Greetwell]] to the south, Nettleham and [[Reepham, Lincolnshire|Reepham]], then [[Sudbrooke]] and Reepham. It passes Sudbrooke to the south, where there is a [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2668667 crossroads], with the main road for Sudbrooke to the left, and [[Star Energy]]'s [[Welton, Lincolnshire|Welton]] Gathering Centre (in Reepham) for the Welton oilfield (part of the [[East Midlands Oil Province]]). The Cherry Tree Cafe is at the [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1152043 junction]. It passes to the south of Sudbrooke Park (a Scout camp site), and [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2490373 crosses] the Lincoln to [[Grimsby]] railway in the parish of [[Barlings]], next to the ''Oriental Express Restaurant'' (former ''[https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/421180 Station Inn]''). At [[Langworth]] there is a crossroads for [[Scothern]], to the left, and Barlings, to the right, and passes St Hugh's [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/93727 church] and ''[http://lincolnshirebrewingco.co.uk/ The George at Langworth]''. It crosses the [[Barlings Eau]] at Langworth Bridge and there is a left turn for [[Stainton by Langworth]], and a right turn for [[Newball]], and the [[Woodside Wildlife and Falconry Park]].[http://www.woodsidefalconry.com Woodside Falconry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425141452/http://www.woodsidefalconry.com/ |date=25 April 2012 }} Further on in the parish of Stainton by Langworth, near [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/329930 Rand Wood], the B1399 heads north-east while the A158 changes direction and heads east to [[Wragby]]. In [[Bullington, Lincolnshire|Bullington]] it passes [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/329961 Bullington Hall] and in [[Rand, Lincolnshire|Rand]], it passes Brown Cow Farm, and there is a left [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2668677 turn] for Rand and [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2511568 Rand Farm Park].[http://www.randfarmpark.com Rand Farm Park] The [[Rand Group]] construction company was [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/330001 based] there until October 2009 when it went into administration. It is briefly the parish boundary between Rand, to the north, and [[Goltho]], to the south, and [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/330027 passes] Goltho Gardens,[http://www.golthogardens.com Goltho Gardens] with a teashop. Approaching Wragby it enters [[East Lindsey]]. Here it [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2668679 crosses] the B1202 at traffic lights near the ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120425141507/http://www.turnorarmswragby.co.uk/ Turnor Arms]'' then forks with the [[A157 road|A157]] which heads through the [[Lincolnshire Wolds]] to [[Louth, Lincolnshire|Louth]]. The A157 formerly followed the A158's current route to Lincoln, and the A158's western terminus was at Wragby before the 1940s. It passes the parish church of All Saints, and crosses the former [[Louth to Bardney Line]]. From here the route gets quite twisty then heads south-east around the south end of the Wolds. It crosses Stainfield Back at [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/330131 Langton Bridge], and passes through [[Langton by Wragby]], where there is a left turn on a bend for [[Panton, Lincolnshire|Panton]], then a right turn on a bend for Chambers Farm Wood,[http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandLincolnshireNoForestChambersFarmWood Chambers Farm Wood] part of the [[Lincolnshire Limewoods]] nature reserve.[http://microsites.lincolnshire.gov.uk/limewoods/about/limewoods-project/partners/ Lincolnshire Limewoods] At [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/390505 Hatton Bridge], it is the parish boundary between Langton by Wragby, to the west and [[Hatton, Lincolnshire|Hatton]], to the east. There are [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2534096 crossroads] for Hatton, to the left, and another crossroads at the (unoccupied) ''[https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/390517 New Midge Inn]'', where the road becomes the parish boundary with [[Minting]] to the south. At [[Baumber]] the B1225 joins from the north as the A158 continues towards in a more southerly direction towards the town of [[Horncastle, Lincolnshire|Horncastle]]. The B1190 and B1191 both join just outside Horncastle where the road crosses the [[A153 road|A153]]. ==Horncastle to Skegness== [[File:The George and Dragon, Hagworthingham - geograph.org.uk - 1316704.jpg|thumb|left|The A158 in [[Hagworthingham]]]] After leaving Horncastle the route heads east with the [[B1195 road|B1195]] heading off {{convert|2.6|mi}} later to [[Spilsby]]. Further on the road passes through the village of Hagworthingham. The road then reaches a roundabout with the [[A16 road (England)|A16]] at [[Partney]]. Both roads used to go through Partney but now bypass it. The construction of this bypass was preceded by a significant archaeological investigation.{{cite web |url=http://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/archsearch/record.jsf |title=Land at Partney bypass |publisher=Archaeology Data Service |date=2005 |accessdate=4 April 2013}}{{cite book |title=Archaeological Excavations Along the Partney By-pass, Lincolnshire (a16/a158) |first1=Robert |last1=Atkins |first2=Elizabeth Shepherd |last2=Popescu |first3=Jon (ill.) |last3=Cane |isbn=978-1904452171 |publisher=Cambridge county council |date=August 2005}}The A158 continues east until reaching another roundabout with the [[A1028 road|A1028]] which provides a short cut from the A16 further north. The B1196 also heads up to [[Alford, Lincolnshire|Alford]] from here. The A158 becomes dual-carriageway for {{convert|1|mi}} from here until becoming single again through Gunby. The road then joins with the newly opened [[Burgh Bypass]], before finally reaching Skegness where it terminates at a junction with the [[A52 road|A52]] {{nowrap|({{coord|53.1496|0.3395|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A158 road (eastern end)}}).}} {{GeoGroupTemplate}} {{UK primary routes 1}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.sabre-roads.org.uk/wiki/index.php?title=A158 SABRE Roads] {{coord|53.2078|-0.1011|dim:30000_region:GB|display=title|name=A158 road}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1-0158}} [[Category:Roads in England]] [[Category:Roads in Lincolnshire]] [[Category:West Lindsey District]] [[Category:East Lindsey District]]

{{Infobox beach | patrolled = | name = Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast | image = Amphitheatre_of_durres_albania_2016.jpg | image_upright = 1.25 | alt = The amphitheatre of the city of Durrës and its port in the background. | caption = The [[Amphitheatre of Durrës|amphitheatre]] of the city of [[Durrës]] and its [[Port of Durrës|port]] in the background. | pushpin_map = Europe#Albania | pushpin_map_size = 280 | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_relief = 1 | pushpin_label = | pushpin_label_position = | location = [[Adriatic Sea]] in [[Albania]]
[[Southern Europe]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|20|10|N|19|27|46|E|display=inline}} | access = | beach_length = {{convert|274|km}} | beach_number = | hazard_rating = | patrolled_by = | activities = | last = [[Montenegro]] | next = [[Albanian Ionian Sea Coast]] }} The '''Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast''' ({{IPA-sq|brɛˈɡdɛ:ti adriˈa:tik}} — {{Lang-sq|Bregdeti Adriatik}}) stretches along the [[Adriatic Sea|Southeastern Adriatic Sea]] that begins from the [[Gulf of Drin]] in the north, across the port cities of [[Shëngjin]], [[Durrës]] and [[Vlorë]], to the [[Bay of Vlorë]] in the south, where the [[Albanian Riviera]] and [[Albanian Ionian Sea Coast]] begins. Albania is geographically positioned in [[Southeastern Europe]] within the western portion of the [[Balkan Peninsula]]. It borders on [[Montenegro]] to the northwest, [[Kosovo]] to the northeast, [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] to the east, [[Greece]] to the south and the [[Mediterranean Sea]] to the west. The total length of the coastline is approximately {{convert|274|km}}, {{convert|178|km}} of which are taken up by white sandy [[beach]]es and the remaining by different [[landform]]s.{{cite book|title=Sustainable Development of Sea-Corridors and Coastal Waters: The TEN ECOPORT project in South East Europe|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319113852|page=85|edition=Chrysostomos Stylios, Tania Floqi, Jordan Marinski, Leonardo Damiani|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OynyBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=length+of+the+ionian+sea+albania#v=onepage&q=length%20of%20the%20ionian%20sea%20albania&f=false|date=2015-04-07}}{{cite web|author1=Pano Niko, Frashe˛ri Alfred, Avdyli Bardhyl and Hoxhaj Fatos|title=Impact of the Climate Change on Adriatic Sea Hydrology|url=http://itc.upt.al/~nfra/A.Frasheri_kerkime_gjeofizike/Addendum-Artikuj-te-perzgedhur-2012-2014/9-%20Pano%20N%20et%20al%20-%20Impact%20of%20Climate%20Change%20on%20Adriatic%20Sea%20Hydrology%20-%20IAEG2014%20Pages%20from%20Proceedings%20381-394.pdf|website=itc.upt.al|page=385|language=English|format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=OUTLOOK ON SEAWATERS DYNAMICS AND GEOLOGICAL SETTING FACTORS FOR THE ALBANIAN ADRIATIC COASTLINE DEVELOPMENTS|url=http://itc.upt.al/~nfra/papers/geosciences/outlook-on-Albanian-Adriatic-coastline-development.pdf|website=itc.upt.al|page=1|language=English|format=PDF}} The [[Adriatic Sea]] is the northernmost arm of the Mediterranean Sea extending all the way from the [[Strait of Otranto]] in the south up to the [[Po Valley]] in the north.{{cite web |title=Adriatic Sea |url=http://arctic.ucalgary.ca/sites/arctic.ucalgary.ca/files/MAKMuir-AdriaticSeaArticle.pdf |website=arctic.ucalgary.ca |language=English |format=PDF}} The sea is apportioned into two major [[Adriatic Basin|basin]]s, wherein Albania is entirely located within the deepest and southernmost one. The coastline is one of the wealthiest scenery of the country in terms of [[biology]], holding an outstanding diversity of [[ecosystem]]s and [[biodiversity]] found within a precious mosaic of [[wetland]]s, [[estuaries]], [[Cape (geography)|cape]]s, [[sand dune]]s, [[marsh]]lands, [[forest]]s and [[marine habitat]]s. At different times, numerous ancient people, most notably the [[Illyrians]]{{sfn|Cunliffe|2008|pp=115–116}}{{sfn|Wilkes|1995|pp=91–104}} and later the [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greeks]] and [[Ancient Rome|Romans]], have established important settlements around the shores. They were considerably influenced by their direct proximity to the sea because it provided routes for trade, colonization and war, as well as food; the [[Via Egnatia]], that crossed through the mountains of Albania, was at that time among the most important routes in the [[Roman Empire]]. The coastline is populated by more than 1.500.000 million people. The [[List of cities in Albania|largest cities]] are [[Durrës]] and [[Vlorë]] placed in the north and south, respectively.{{cite web |title=SOME CONSIDERATIONS ON SEAWATER-FRESHWATER RELATIONSHIP IN ALBANIAN COASTAL AREA |url=http://www.igme.es/igme/publica/tiac-02/ALBANIA-I.pdf |website=igme.es |location=Tirana |page=2 |language=English |format=PDF}} Durrës is served by [[Port of Durrës]], one of the largest on the Adriatic Sea, which connects the city to [[Italy]] and other neighbouring countries within the Adriatic. == Environment == === Geography === {{See also|Geography of Albania}} Albania is geographically positioned on the [[Balkan Peninsula]] in [[Southeastern Europe]] bordered by the countries of [[Montenegro]] to the northwest, [[Kosovo]] to the northeast, the [[Republic of Macedonia]] to the east and [[Greece]] to the south and southeast. The western edge touches the [[Adriatic Sea|Adriatic]] and [[Ionian Sea]], both within the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. The majority of the country's territory consists of mountains and hills, making Albania one of the most mountainous countries of [[Europe]]. Likely the [[Albanian Alps]] runs in the north the [[Korab|Korab Mountains]] in the east, the [[Ceraunian Mountains]] in the south and the [[Central Mountain Range, Albania#Skanderbeg Mountains|Skanderbeg Mountains]] in the center, while the plains and plateaus are mainly to be found in the west. The [[Albanian Ionian Sea Coast]] is known for its rugged natural beauty, with rocky highlands and a great marine life, while the Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast consist of sandy beaches and shallow coastal waters hosting a great wildlife. Administratively, the Albanian Adriatic coast is shared between the counties of [[Shkodër County|Shkodër]] in the north, [[Lezhë County|Lezhë]], [[Durrës County|Durrës]], [[Tirana County|Tirana]], [[Fier County|Fier]] and [[Vlorë County|Vlorë]] in the south. The Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast begins from the [[estuary]] of [[Bojana (river)|Buna]] whitin the [[Gulf of Drin]] at the border with [[Montenegro]], passes through [[Myzeqe|Myzeqe Plain]], the [[Cape (geography)|cape]]s of [[Cape of Rodon|Rodon]], Turrës, Gjuhëzes, the cities of [[Shëngjin]], [[Durrës]], [[Vlorë]], the [[estuaries]] of [[Drin River|Drin]], [[Mat (river)|Mat]], [[Ishëm (river)|Ishëm]], [[Erzen river|Erzen]], [[Shkumbin River|Shkumbin]], [[Seman (river)|Seman]], [[Vjosë]] and the lagoons of [[Karavasta Lagoon|Karavasta]], [[Narta Lagoon|Narta]] [[Kune-Vain-Tale]] and [[Patoku Lagoon|Patoku]], until it reaches the [[Bay of Vlorë]]. Numerous rivers flowing into the Adriatic Sea form [[bay]]s, [[lagoon]]s and [[Liman (landform)|liman]]s. The [[sand]] and [[silt]] they bring are deposited in the areas of reduced flow, that is the sides of the bays, forming narrow [[Spit (landform)|sandbank]]s. {{wide image|Karavasta National Park Albania 2016.jpg|800px|The [[Karavasta Lagoon]], located within the [[Divjakë-Karavasta National Park]], is among the largest lagoons in the [[Mediterranean Sea]].|center}} === Biodiversity === {{See also|Biodiversity of Albania}} {{multiple image |perrow=2/2/2/1 |total_width=250 | image1 = Green_turtle_swimming_over_coral_reefs_in_Kona.jpg |width1=4224 |height1=3168 | image2 = Vulpes vulpes Kurdistanica (cropped).jpg |width2=3470 |height2=3470 | image3 = Dalmatian_pelican_(Pelecanus_crispus)_in_Divjakë-Karavasta,_Albania.jpg |width3=1152 |height3=1535 | image4 = Anim1069 - Flickr - NOAA Photo Library.jpg |width4=1023 |height4=656 | image5 = Phoenicopterus_roseus_Camargue_5.jpg |width5=1536 |height5=726 | footer = Species such as the [[green sea turtle]], [[red fox]], [[dalmatian pelican]], [[common bottlenose dolphin]] and [[greater flamingo]] thrive in the Albanian [[Adriatic Sea]] Coast.}} In terms of [[phytogeography]], the Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast belongs to the [[Illyria]]n province of the [[Circumboreal Region]] within the [[Boreal Kingdom]]. It falls entirely within the [[Illyrian deciduous forests]] terrestrial [[ecoregion]] of the [[Palearctic ecozone|Palearctic]] [[Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub]]. The special environmental circumstances and the millennial human activity on the territory of the coast determine the rich variety of species, populations and [[ecosystem]]s, many of which are with conservation significance. The Albanian Adriatic portion features contrasting [[vegetation]] types that are impacted by different factors. The [[woodland]]s are mostly dominated by [[evergreen forest]]s with associated [[broadleaved]] [[sclerophyllous]] evergreen trees and shrubs primarily found in the southern section of the coastline.{{cite web |title=DISTRIBUTION OF MAMMALS IN ALBANIA |url=http://catsg.org/balkanlynx/07_library/7_2_publications/Pdfs/Prigioni_1996_Mammals_in_Albania.pdf |website=catsg.org |language=English |format=PDF}} The forests ranges from mixed [[broadleaf forest]]s, at lower elevations, to [[conifer forest]]s, at higher elevations.{{cite web |title=420: Southeast Adriatic Drainages |url=http://www.feow.org/ecoregions/details/southeast_adriatic_drainages |website=feow.org |language=English}} The [[pine]] forms an important natural feature within the coastline, that is distributed across [[Buna River-Velipoja Protected Landscape|Velipoja]], [[Shëngjin]], [[Patoku Lagoon|Patok]] and [[Cape of Rodon|Rodon]], which in turn provide habitat for a vast array of wildlife.{{cite book |title=Protection of Coastal Areas of the Adriatic Sea: Proceedings : Colloquy Organised Within the Framework of European Nature Conservation Year 1995 in Co-operation with the Ministry of Health and Environment of Albania, Tirana, Albania, 27-29 October 1994 |publisher=Council of Europe, 1995 |isbn=9789287128515 |page=68 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=DMkEEnCwi18C&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68&dq=pine+forests+albanian+adriatic+sea#v=onepage&q=pine%20forests%20albanian%20adriatic%20sea&f=false |language=English|date=1995-01-01 }} Stretching in the southeastern [[Adriatic Sea]], the coast with a wealth of important [[habitat]]s makes for a fascinating birdwatching location during peak [[Bird migration|migration]] with several [[wetland]]s, [[estuaries]] and hills provides diversity for both resident and migrant [[bird]]s.{{cite web |title=Conservation Status of Albanian Coastal Wetlands and their Colonial Waterbird Populations (Pelecaniformes and Ciconiiformes) |url=http://www.vliz.be/imisdocs/publications/235127.pdf |website=vliz.be |location=Brussels |pages=1–10 |language=English |format=PDF}} Maybe the most iconic bird of the coast is the [[vulnerable species|vulnerable]] and extremely rare [[dalmatian pelican]].{{cite web |author1=Euronatur |title=Dalmatian Pelicans |url=https://www.euronatur.org/en/what-we-do/endangered-species/migratory-birds/protecting-migrating-birds/projects/dalmatian-pelicans/ |website=euronatur.org |language=English}} It breeds on inland lakes and coastal lagoons of Albania such as in [[Karavasta Lagoon|Karavasta]] and [[Patoku Lagoon]].{{cite web |author1=[[IUCN Red List]] |title=Pelecanus crispus (Dalmatian pelican) |url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22697599/0 |website=iucnredlist.org |language=English}} The [[greater flamingo]] is another prominent and important species that live in the region. It is the largest species of [[flamingo]] and widespread in Karavasta and [[Narta Lagoon]].{{cite web |author1=[[BirdLife International]] and [[IUCN Red List]] |title=Phoenicopterus roseus (Greater Flamingo) |url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/userfiles/file/Species/erlob/supplementarypdfs/22697360_phoenicopterus_roseus.pdf |website=datazone.birdlife.org |page=3 |language=English |format=PDF}} The coast is famous for [[wildlife]] watching and nesting [[sea turtle]]s are one of the region's highlights. Its beaches provide nesting sites for several species of [[endangered sea turtles]], namely the [[hawksbill sea turtle|hawksbill]], [[Leatherback sea turtle|leatherback]], [[green sea turtle|green sea]] and [[loggerhead sea turtle]].{{cite web |title=Loggerhead turtles (Caretta caretta) foraging at Drini Bay in Northern Albania: Genetic characterisation reveals new haplotypes |url=http://fupress.net/index.php/ah/article/viewFile/10286/12001 |website=fupress.net |location=Tirana, Albania |pages=1–8 |language=English |format=PDF}}{{cite web |author1=IUCN |title=Sea turtles in the Mediterranean: Distribution, threats and conservation priorities |url=http://www.rac-spa.org/sites/default/files/doc_turtles/med-turtle-report.pdf |website=rac-spa.org |pages=23–36 |language=English |format=PDF}}{{cite web |title=Report on the status and conservation of the Leatherback Turtle Dermochelys coriacea |url=https://www.cms.int/sites/default/files/document/Doc_05_Attach3_LeatherbackTurtles_E_0.pdf |website=cms.int |language=English |format=PDF}}{{cite web |title=Distribution records of sea turtles in the Montenegrin waters |url=http://www.ucg.ac.me/skladiste/blog_1223/objava_9609/fajlovi/Distribution%20records%20of%20sea%20turtles%20in%20the%20Montenegrin%20waters.pdf |website=ucg.ac.me |language=English |format=PDF}} As well as turtles, the sea life consist of several species of [[shark]]s, [[dolphin]]s and [[whale]]s. The [[cuvier's beaked whale]] and [[sperm whale]] are common along the coast. The dolphin species found along the entire coastline are represented by the [[striped dolphin]], [[risso's dolphin]] and [[common bottlenose dolphin]].{{cite web |author1=United Nations Environment Programme MEDITERRANEAN ACTION PLAN |title=STATUS AND CONSERVATION OF CETACEANS IN THE ADRIATIC SEA |url=https://www.cbd.int/doc/meetings/mar/ebsaws-2014-03/other/ebsaws-2014-03-submission-rac-spa-sr-01-en.pdf |website=cbd.int |page=22 |language=English |format=PDF}}{{cite web |title=Inland observations of Common Bottlenose Dolphins Tursiops truncatus (Montagu, 1821) in the delta of the Bojana/Buna River, Albania and Montenegro |url=https://www.dlib.si/stream/URN:NBN:SI:DOC-6WHOO0JG/684d4f8a-aef3-4571-8a05-4ff7fa22e55f/PDF |website=dlib.si |pages=1–4 |language=English |format=PDF}} The vast and diverse coast is home to an incredibly rich diversity of [[mammal]]s. Most famous of the [[carnivore]]s is the rare [[golden jackal]] that occurs mostly on the coast of the ravines of the rivers.{{cite web |author1=[[World Wide Fund for Nature]] Greece |title=Conservation Action Plan for the golden jackal (Canis aureus) in Greece |url=https://www.wwf.gr/images/pdfs/jackalactionplan.pdf |website=wwf.gr |page=8 |language=English |format=PDF}}{{cite book |author1=Marco Masseti |title=Atlas of terrestrial mammals of the Ionian and Aegean islands |publisher=Walter de Gruyter, 2012 |isbn=9783110254587 |page=107 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y4J0Hzo0o4gC&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&dq=golden+jackal+albania#v=onepage&q=golden%20jackal%20albania&f=false |language=English|date=2012-10-30 }}{{cite web |author1=Euronatur |title=Rapid assessment of the Ecological Value of the Bojana-Buna Delta (Albania / Montenegro) |url=https://www.euronatur.org/fileadmin/migration/uploads/media/Chap_6_Rapid_assessment_of_the_Ecological_Value_of_the_Bojana-Buna_Delta_01.pdf |website=euronatur.org |language=English |format=PDF}} Another notorious might be the [[red fox]], which occurs throughout the forested and coastal areas in the northern section of the coast.{{cite web |author1=[[IUCN]] |title=Request for Proposals Design and realization of museological exhibits for the Buna River Protected Landscape and the Shebenik-Jabllanicë National Park visitor centres in Albania |url=https://www.iucn.org/downloads/rfp_iucn_alb_ecomuseums_webpub.pdf |website=iucn.org |page=44 |language=English |format=PDF}} Other mammals include the [[brown bear]], [[wild boar]], [[chamois]] and [[grey wolf]]. The sea, lagoons and river deltas are extremely rich in salt and fresh water [[fish]]. Some aquatic animals, that are abundant, include the [[european sea sturgeon]], [[starry sturgeon]], [[twait shad]] and [[adriatic sturgeon]], which is perhaps the most famous species to become extinct in the Adriatic Sea. [[File:Albania. - panoramio.jpg|240px|thumb|right|The [[Drainage basin|catchment area]] of [[Drin River|Drin]] is classified as one of the most important [[biodiversity hotspot]]s in [[Europe]].{{cite web|title=The natural wealth and legacy of the Drin River Basin: inspiring our collective actions|url=http://act4drin.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Act4Drin_Brochure_18_9_2015_single_pages.pdf|website=act4drin.net|page=7|language=English|format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=Drin River Basin The blue heart of the Balkans|url=http://mio-ecsde.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/drin-river-basin_brochure_02.pdf|website=mio-ecsde.org|page=4|language=English|format=PDF}}]] The [[protected areas of Albania]] are a biodiversity treasure, containing a wide range of geographical and climatic diversity. Different categories of [[protected area]]s have been established alongside the coast. [[Divjakë-Karavasta National Park]], the only [[national park]] in the Albanian Adriatic coast, is very picturesque and harbors several [[endangered species]], that makes it a very popular place indeed. Encompassing the [[Drin River]] [[estuary]], the [[Kunë-Vain-Tale Nature Park]] is an undisturbed natural area of wet [[grassland]]s, [[swamp]]s and [[lagoon]]s at the direct proximity to the Adriatic Sea. The [[Vjosa]], which is considered to be Europe's last wild river, discharges, north of [[Narta Lagoon|Narta]], into the Adriatic Sea, where it forms the [[Vjosa-Narta Protected Landscape]].{{cite web|author1=Fred Pearce|title=Scientists demand halt to damming of Europe's last wild river|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2106908-scientists-demand-halt-to-damming-of-europes-last-wild-river/|website=newscientist.com|accessdate=23 September 2016|language=English}} Both, the Karavasta Lagoon and [[Lake Shkodër]], are classified as [[wetland]]s of international importance by designation under the [[Ramsar Convention]].{{cite web|author1=[[Ramsar Convention]]|title=KARAVASTA LAGOON MANAGEMENT PLAN|url=http://ramsar.rgis.ch/cda/es/ramsar-documents-wurl-plans-ramsar-site-management-22009/main/ramsar/1-31-116-163%5E22009_4000_2__|website=ramsar.rgis.ch|language=English}}{{cite web|title=Raport Paraprakë Vleresim Ndikimi Në Mjedis|url=http://www.akm.gov.al/assets/3.-vnm-paraprake-rr.mertish-tre-ura.pdf|website=akm.gov.al|page=12|language=Albanian|format=PDF}}{{cite web |author1=[[Ramsar Convention]] |title=Albania designates its share of Lake Shkodra |url=https://www.ramsar.org/news/albania-designates-its-share-of-lake-shkodra |website=ramsar.org |language=English |date=7 February 2006}} [[Important Bird Area]]s are important sites for bird conservation and their habitats, as they provide suitable conditions to birds. Currently, [[List of Important Bird Areas in Albania|16 important bird area]]s have been identified throughout the territory of Albania, amongst them the [[Drin River|Drin Delta]] near [[Shkodër]], the [[Vlorë Bay]], that is bordered by [[Karaburun-Sazan Marine Park]], and the lagoons of Patoku, Karavasta and Narta, that are among the largest and most important coastal wetlands of the Balkans, due to its varied biodiversity and one of the top sites for wintering and migratory birds in the country.{{cite web|author1=[[BirdLife International]]|title=Albania|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/results?cty=2&fam=0&gen=0|website=datazone.birdlife.org|page=1|language=English}}{{cite web |author1=[[BirdLife International]] |title=Important Bird Areas and potential Ramsar Sites in Europe |url=http://www.birdlife.org/sites/default/files/attachments/ibas_ramsar_europe_0_0.pdf |website=birdlife.org |pages=18–19 |language=English |format=PDF}} === Climate === {{See also|Climate of Albania}} Apart from the considerable variation in landscape, it makes for a wide range of climate types. The [[Adriatic Sea]] in the west, [[Albanian Alps]] in the north and [[Ceraunian Mountains]] in the south have a great influence to the climate of the area. As defined by the [[Köppen climate classification]], the Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast experiences a [[mediterranean climate#Hot-summer Mediterranean climate|mediterranean climate]] with considerable [[Oceanic climate|maritime]] and [[Humid subtropical climate|subtropical]] influences. This means that the summers are hot, sometimes very hot and dry and the winters generally mild and wet. The coast experiences four distinct seasons. The winter is relatively humid and mild, and the summer lasts very long and is usually hot and dry. Autumn and spring are transitional seasons. [[Wind]]s in the Adriatic Sea change their direction and speed during a year period as a result of the distinctive mediterranean climate. This characteristic is mainly determined by a passing trajectory of basic systems across the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and [[Balkan Peninsula]] as well as other important factors such as morphometric characteristics of the territory. {{Weather box |location = Durrës |metric first = yes |single line = yes |Jan high C = 11.4 |Feb high C = 12.5 |Mar high C = 14.9 |Apr high C = 18.3 |May high C = 22.6 |Jun high C = 26.5 |Jul high C = 28.7 |Aug high C = 28.8 |Sep high C = 26.0 |Oct high C = 21.4 |Nov high C = 16.6 |Dec high C = 13.3 |Jan mean C = 8.1 |Feb mean C = 9.0 |Mar mean C = 10.9 |Apr mean C = 14.0 |May mean C = 18.1 |Jun mean C = 21.8 |Jul mean C = 23.8 |Aug mean C = 23.9 |Sep mean C = 21.2 |Oct mean C = 17.2 |Nov mean C = 13.0 |Dec mean C = 9.9 |Jan low C = 4.8 |Feb low C = 5.6 |Mar low C = 6.9 |Apr low C = 9.7 |May low C = 13.6 |Jun low C = 17.2 |Jul low C = 19.0 |Aug low C = 19.0 |Sep low C = 16.5 |Oct low C = 13.0 |Nov low C = 9.5 |Dec low C = 6.5 |precipitation colour = green |Jan precipitation mm = 132 |Feb precipitation mm = 107 |Mar precipitation mm = 99 |Apr precipitation mm = 81 |May precipitation mm = 68 |Jun precipitation mm = 41 |Jul precipitation mm = 26 |Aug precipitation mm = 36 |Sep precipitation mm = 71 |Oct precipitation mm = 112 |Nov precipitation mm = 160 |Dec precipitation mm = 131 |source = {{cite web |url = https://en.climate-data.org/location/907625/ |title = Climate: Durrës |publisher = Climate-Data.org |access-date = February 2, 2018}} }} == Economy == === Tourism === {{See also|Tourism in Albania}} [[File:Apollonia, Albania (by Pudelek) - Monument of Agonothetes.JPG|240px|thumb|right|The fascinating architectural heritage of [[Apollonia (Illyria)|Apollonia]] attracts hundreds of tourists.]] [[Tourism]] is considered one of the largest industries in the [[economy of Albania]].{{cite web |title=TOURISM AND EMPLOYMENT IN ALBANIA – IS THERE A STRONG CORRELATION? |url=http://www.asecu.gr/files/13th_conf_files/Tourism-and-Employment-in-Albania-Is-There-A-Strong-Correlation.pdf |website=asecu.gr |pages=1–9 |language=English |format=PDF}} It has significantly increased since following the [[fall of communism in Albania|fall of communism]] in the country.{{cite web |author1=Eglantina Hysa - Epoka University |title=INFLUENCE OF TOURISM SECTOR IN ALBANIAN GDP: ESTIMATION USING MULTIPLE REGRESSION METHOD |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/308111717 |website=researchgate.net |location=Tirana |pages=1–6 |language=English |format=PDF}} The country has a rich [[History of Albania|historical]] and [[Culture of Albania|cultural]] heritage and natural beauty varying from clear turquoise waters fringed by sandy and rocky beaches to contrasting mountainous interior. The coastline has a well-preserved natural [[ecosystem]] that can boast a unique combination of a diverse [[climate]] and [[landscape]]. As [[Albania]] extends over the Adriatic flyway, [[birdwatching]] is recently gaining in popularity, due to the interest shown by visitors from other countries.{{cite web |author1=Euronatur |title=Adriatic Flyway |url=https://www.euronatur.org/en/what-we-do/endangered-species/migratory-birds/campaign-on-bird-hunting/adriatic-flyway/ |website=euronatur.org |language=English}}{{cite web |author1=Euronatur |title=ADRIATIC FLYWAY - BIRD CONSERVATION ON THE BALKANS |url=https://www.euronatur.org/fileadmin/docs/Vogeljagd-Kampagne/Adriatic_Flyway_Proceedings_04-05-17.pdf |website=euronatur.org |language=English |format=PDF}} The coastline has a lot to offer fr both visiting and resident [[bird]] watchers.{{cite web |author1=[[Lonely Planet]] |title=Albania develops birdwatching in Adriatic wetlands to boost tourism |url=https://www.lonelyplanet.com/news/2016/05/03/albania-birdwatching-adriatic/ |website=lonelyplanet.com |language=English |format=PDF}} The extensive [[wetland]]s, with many different Mediterranean and European species, contains many significant birding sites throughout the year. The lagoons in [[Karavasta Lagoon|Karavasta]], [[Patoku Lagoon|Patoku]], [[Narta Lagoon|Narta]] and various other protected areas are just a few examples of popular birdwatching destinations. Beach vacations, particularly for domestic and foreign visitors from different countries, are also central to the local tourism industry. Most beach resorts are located especially along the coastline of [[Durrës]] and [[Vlorë]]. The southern coastline of Durrës are renowned for its traditional [[mass tourism]], which have experienced an uncontrolled urban development. In contrast, the northern coastline are mostly unspoiled and set to become an elite tourism destination as a number of beach resorts are being built. The heritage tourism is focussed on specific interest on the [[history of Albania]], such as the architectural heritage of ancient civilizations such as the [[Illyrians]], [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greeks]] and [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] in Albania. Besides the churches, mosques, forts and historical buildings, the most popular heritage tourism attractions are the remains of the ancient city of [[Apollonia (Illyria)|Apollonia]], the ancient fortress of [[Rozafa Castle|Rozafa]] and the [[amphitheatre]] of [[Amphitheatre of Durrës|Durrës]]. === Transport === {{See also|Transport in Albania}} [[File:Panorama of Durres Port.jpg|240px|thumb|right|Panorama of the [[Port of Durrës]].]] The Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast is home to the three largest [[seaport]]s of the country. The largest cargo ports among them is the [[Port of Durrës]], one of the largest in the Adriatic Sea, with annual passenger volume of approximately 1.5 million. The other seaports include [[Port of Vlorë|Vlorë]] and [[Port of Shëngjin|Shëngjin]]. In addition, the ports serve a wide system of ferries, connecting numerous islands and coastal cities in addition to ferry lines to several cities in [[Croatia]], [[Greece]] and [[Italy]]. [[Yachting]] is pretty recent in the country and less developed than in other countries within the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. ''Porto Albania'' will be after its complementation, the first marina destination in Albania for both national and international yachting and charter.{{cite web |title=Porto Albania – Erster Mega-Yachthafen Albaniens: Startschuss für Bauarbeiten fällt |url=https://aussenden.com/porto-albania-erster-mega-yachthafen-albaniens-startschuss-fuer-bauarbeiten-faellt/ |website=aussenden.com |language=German |date=18 May 2017}} It will be located between the city of Durrës and the national park of [[Divjakë-Karavasta National Park|Divjakë-Karavasta]]. == See also == {{commons category|Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast}} * [[Adriatic Sea]] * [[Geography of Albania]] * [[Biodiversity of Albania]] * [[List of Important Bird Areas in Albania|Important Bird Areas in Albania]] * [[Albanian Ionian Sea Coast]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Navboxes | title = [[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Albania.svg|20x20px]] Topics related to the Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast | titlestyle = color:black; background-color:white; |list1= {{Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast}} {{Albania topics}} }} {{Portal bar|Environment|Albania}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast}} [[Category:Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast| ]] [[Category:Geography of Albania]] [[Category:Adriatic Sea]] [[Category:Coasts of Albania| ]] [[Category:Coasts of the Mediterranean Sea]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Albania| ]]

revision.text:
The '''Alberta Township System (ATS)''' is a land [[surveying]] system used in the [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] of [[Alberta]] and other parts of [[western Canada]].
==History and background== In principle there is a mathematical basis for the Alberta Township System (ATS) variant of the [[Dominion Land Survey]] (DLS) system as implemented in Canada. The implementation in western Canada reflects a number of slightly different approaches, as well as a large number of errors.
Long before the Dominion Land Surveyor (DLS) first came into official existence in 1872, licensed surveyors known as Provincial Land Surveyors had been functioning in the Provinces of [[Ontario]] and [[Quebec]] (then called [[Canada West]] and [[Canada East]]) under an Act of 1849. Establishing a system of examination for new aspirants to the title of "Dominion Land Surveyor" was officially adopted in 1874. In 1910 The Alberta Surveyors Act prescribed the system and the methods whereby land surveys were to be carried out under the general purview of a provincial Director of Surveys whose responsibility it was to see that all survey work was performed in accordance with the provisions of that Act.<ref>{{Cite web| url= http://www.landsurveyinghistory.ab.ca/ALSAStory/Association_Story-1905.htm| title= Alberta's Survey History| author= Alberta Land Surveyors' Association| accessdate= 2007-02-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070227215435/http://www.landsurveyinghistory.ab.ca/ALSAStory/Association_Story-1905.htm| archivedate= 2007-02-27| deadurl= yes| df= }}</ref>
The system is also used by provincial governments when selling exploration rights, and oil and gas wells are referenced by their location as defined within the Alberta Township System.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://chinookconsulting.ca/News/Alberta-Township-System.html|title=Alberta Township System|accessdate=2011-04-04}}</ref>
==How it works== [[File:Dominion-land-system-overview.png|thumb|right|300px|Townships in relation with meridians, baselines and correction lines]] Below is a brief description of how to lay out the [[Dominion Land Survey|DLS]] grid for [[Alberta]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alsa.ab.ca/system.htm |title=Alberta's Township System |author=Alberta Land Surveyors' Association |accessdate=2007-02-13 |date=February 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202090722/http://www.alsa.ab.ca/system.htm |archivedate=2007-02-02 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ags.gov.ab.ca/gis/map_converters/map_conversion_explanation.html |title=Alberta Township System (ATS) |author=Alberta Geological Survey |date=July 2009 |accessdate=2009-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420145953/http://www.ags.gov.ab.ca/gis/map_converters/map_conversion_explanation.html |archivedate=2009-04-20 }}</ref>
Lay off {{convert|6.0375|mi|km|adj=on}} ticks from the [[49th parallel north|49th parallel]] of latitude to the [[60th parallel north|60th parallel]]. This gives 127 [[township]] lines.
The 49th parallel of [[latitude]] is the first base line of the ATS system. On it lay off {{convert|6.0750|mi|km|adj=on}} ticks westwards starting at the [[110th meridian west|110th line]] of [[longitude]] (4th DLS meridian). Start over at the [[114th meridian west|114th]] and [[118th meridian west|118th]] lines of longitude (5th and 6th DLS meridians). Extend these ticks {{convert|12.0750|mi|km}} due north (following a line of constant longitude) to the first correction line. This gets you your first set of range lines.
Starting at the 49th parallel (first base line) go {{convert|24.1500|mi|km}} directly north. This gets you to the second base line. At the latitude corresponding to this distance from the 49th parallel lay off {{convert|6.0750|mi|km|adj=on}} ticks westwards from 110th [[Meridian (geography)|meridian]] as you did at the 1st base line. The circumference of the earth has decreased as you went northwards, so there will be fewer full ticks than there were one base line south. Extend {{convert|12.0750|mi|km}} north and {{convert|12.0750|mi|km}} south from these ticks. This gets you your next set of range lines. You will note there is an offset between the range lines extending north from the lower base line and those extending south from the current ones. This offset occurs along what is called a correction line.
Repeat the base line process every {{convert|24.1500|mi|km}} northwards (to the 32nd).
All this will result in a mesh of cells nominally six miles (plus 3 or 6 [[chain (unit)|chain]]s for road allowances) on a side. Each such cell is called a township (not to be confused with the township lines laid off earlier). Subdivide the township into 36 sections by laying off ticks of one-sixth of each township side and connecting them by north-south and east-west lines. The sections are numbered [[sinusoidally]] starting from the southeast corner of the township.
Sections can be similarly subdivided into quarters by placing and connecting ticks at the halfway point on each section side. Use the same process to subdivide sections into legal [[subdivision (land)|subdivisions]] (LSD) except place the tick at the one-quarter waypoints. LSDs are numbered sinusoidally starting at the southeast corner of the section.
While the ATS format is still [[Property|proprietary]], online conversion tools have been developed.
*Alberta Geological Survey converts the system to [[geographical coordinates]]<ref>{{Cite web | url= http://www.ags.gov.ab.ca/gis/map_converters/conversion_tools.html | title= Alberta Township System (ATS) and Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) Cartographic Conversion Tools | author= Alberta Geological Survey | date= July 2009 | accessdate= 2009-07-28 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090515113632/http://www.ags.gov.ab.ca/gis/map_converters/conversion_tools.html | archivedate= 2009-05-15 | df= }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Dominion Land Survey]] *[[List of settlements in Alberta]]
==External links== * [http://www.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?useExisting=1&layers=e7e309c9bae94618807e7733133053d5 Map Service from AgCanada: Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba: quarter-sections, sections, and townships. Ontario: geographic townships and concession lots. To view fabric for each province, expand "Canada Land Parcels" in contents and enable layers.] * [http://www.baseloc.com/dls/ LSD + GPS + UTM coordinates (batch) conversion ] Free map converters & tools * [http://www1.aer.ca/GISConversionTools/conversion_tools.html Conversion tools from Alberta Government] * [http://sites.google.com/site/atsmapcreator/ ATS Mapper] Create Alberta Township System geo-referenced KML maps that can be viewed in Google Earth or ArcGIS. License:PWYW
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of Alberta]] [[Category:Land surveying systems]] [[Category:Surveying]]

revision.comment: Minor change to mention of 1992 date to correct misconception this list is for all honours awarded afterwards (it isn't, only Imperial).
revision.text:
The Governor General of Australia has, at irregular intervals, notified for general information the positioning of the wearing of Australian Orders, Decorations and Medals in the ''Commonwealth of Australia Gazette''. The '''''Order of Wearing Australian Honours and Awards''''' was last published in 2007, and replaced the previous list published in 2002.''Commonwealth of Australia Gazette'' No. S101 of Thursday, 4 April 2002 and No. S192 of Friday, 28 September 2007 Prior to 2002, the lists were named the ''Australian Order of Precedence of Honours and Awards''.e.g. ''Commonwealth of Australia Gazette'' No. S113 of Wednesday, 9 May 1990 and No. S26 of Monday, 4 February 1991 With the cessation in 2013 of the gazettal of lists of recipients of Australia Day and Queen’s Birthday Honours, it is not yet known if future issues of the ''Order of Wearing Australian Honours and Awards'' will be gazetted.''Commonwealth of Australia Gazette'' No. S15 of Saturday 26 January 2013 is a notice that states: "The Governor-General is pleased to announce appointments and awards to orders and decorations listed with a note that a comprehensive list of recipients can be found at www.gg.gov.au" == Order of Wearing == Order of wearing decorations and awards within the [[Australian Honours System]].[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf "The Order of Wearing Australian Honours and Awards"], updated 25 September 2007. (Includes official post-nominals.) ''It's an Honour'' Honours and Awards listed are: * those within the Australian System of Honours and Awards; * those conferred by The Sovereign in exercise of the [[Royal Prerogative]]; * those within the Order of St John; and * foreign awards, the acceptance and wearing of which have been authorised by the Governor-General. Note that awards of the British Empire/United Kingdom are now considered foreign (if awarded after 5 October 1992), and should be worn accordingly.''"- all Imperial awards made to Australian citizens '''after''' 5 October 1992 are foreign awards and should be worn accordingly."'' [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf ''Order of Wearing''], updated 25 September 2007. page 1. (Generally, foreign awards are worn ''after'' Australian awards, and postnominals of foreign awards are not recognised.) {{See also|Order of Wearing of honours awarded prior to 6 October 1992}} #[[Image:Victoria Cross (UK) ribbon.png|90px]] '''[[Victoria Cross]]/[[Victoria Cross for Australia]]'''''"Refers to both the [[Victoria Cross]] and the [[Victoria Cross for Australia]]."'' [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf ''Order of Wearing''], Page 5, Note 1. (Generally, foreign awards are worn ''after'' Australian awards, and postnominals of foreign awards are not recognised.) The grade was reinstated on 25 March 2014 on the advice of the Prime Minister."'' [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf ''Order of Wearing''], Page 5, Note 2. Medal]]''' #'''Foreign Awards''' (in order of date of authorisation of their acceptance and wearing). == Citations == The following citations are not positioned according to the list above. For members of the uniformed services, they are worn according to respective Service dress rules. For civilians, they are worn centrally above any other honours or awards: * [[Image:AUS Unit Citation for Gallantry with Federation Star.png|90px]] [[Unit Citation for Gallantry]] * [[Image:AUS Meritorious Unit Citation with Federation Star.png|90px]] [[Meritorious Unit Citation]] * [[Image:Group Bravey Citation (Australia).jpg|90px]] [[Group Bravery Citation]] == Foreign awards == Approved foreign awards are published by the Governor-General and may be found on the [https://www.gg.gov.au/schedule-approved-countries-and-awards Schedule of Approved Countries and Awards]. The following are international and foreign honours commonly awarded to Australians for various reasons. {| class=wikitable |- | * [[File:Legion Honneur Commandeur ribbon.svg|90px]] | ''Commandeur'' |rowspan=3| '''[[Legion of Honour]]''' - awarded for Excellent civil or military conduct delivered |rowspan=3| France |- | * [[File:Legion Honneur Officier ribbon.svg|90px]] | ''Officier'' |- | * [[File:Legion Honneur Chevalier ribbon.svg|90px]] | ''Chevalier'' |- | * [[File:Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang (Tentera) ribbon.png|90px]] |colspan=2| '''[[Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang (Tentera)|Distinguished Service Order (Military)]]''' |rowspan=2| Singapore |- | * [[File:Pingat Jasa Gemilang (Tentera) ribbon.png|90px]] |colspan=2| '''[[Pingat Jasa Gemilang (Tentera)|Meritorious Service Medal (Military)]]''' |- | * [[File:Gugseon Security Medal Ribbon.png|90px]] |colspan=2| '''[[Order of National Security Merit (Korea)|Order of National Security Merit]]''' - usually awarded for joint operations | South Korea |- | * [[Image:Order of the British Empire (Civil) Ribbon.png|90px]] | ''Civil'' |rowspan=2| '''[[Order of the British Empire]]''' - awarded for Miscellaneous (civil or military) service |rowspan=2| United Kingdom |- | * [[File:Order of the British Empire (Military) Ribbon.png|90px]] | ''Military'' |- | * [[File:US Legion of Merit Commander ribbon.png|90px]] | ''Commander'' |rowspan=2| '''[[Legion of Merit]]''' - awarded to senior defence commanders |rowspan=3| United States |- | * [[File:Us legion of merit officer rib.png|90px]] | ''Officer'' |- | * [[File:Meritorious Service Medal ribbon.svg|90px]] |colspan=2| '''[[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]]''' - usually awarded for joint operations |} For foreign awards commonly awarded to Australians for campaign and peacekeeping service please refer to the list on [[Australian Campaign Medals]]. == See also == * [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Australia]] * [[Post-nominal letters]] * [[List of post-nominal letters (Australia)]] * [[Australian Commendations and Citations]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links== *[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au It's an Honour] – Australian government website *[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/wearing.cfm#Order ''Wearing Awards''] – Australian government It's an Honour website *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070510031424/http://www.defence.gov.au/medals/Content/%2B050%20Honours%20Policy/%2B010%20Order%20of%20wear/default.htm Defence Honours & Awards]– Australian Defence Force website * [http://www.defence.gov.au/Medals/Content/Policy/Honours-Awards-Manual.asp The Defence Honours and Awards Manual] (DHAM) ** Chapter 4 of the manual includes a link to the "current" (2007) [http://www.defence.gov.au/Medals/_Master/docs/DHAM/04.pdf Order of Wearing], but more usefully: ** [http://www.defence.gov.au/Medals/_Master/docs/DHAM/04A.pdf Annex A] contains: ''A modified order of wearing that is designed to make the order of wearing Defence awards more easily understood'' ... ''The modified version provides a complete list of all awards by incorporating those campaign and other medals that are included separately in annexes to the original schedule.''

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/188.29.164.84|188.29.164.84]] ([[User talk:188.29.164.84|talk]]) to last revision by Randy Kryn. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=September 2009}} The '''''Axe historique''''' ({{IPA-fr|aks istɔʁik|pron}}; {{lang-en|historical axis}}) is a line of monuments, buildings and thoroughfares that extends from the centre of [[Paris]], [[France]], to the west. It is also known as the ''Voie Triomphale'' ("triumphal way"). [[File:Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel, 16 August 2008.jpg|thumb|The [[Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel]], the [[obelisk]] of the [[Place de la Concorde]], the [[Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile]], and the [[Grande Arche]] of [[La Défense]], on the same perspective.]] The Axe Historique began with the creation of the [[Champs Élysées]], designed in the 17th century to create a vista to the west, extending the central axis of the gardens to the royal [[Palace of the Tuileries]]. Today the [[Tuileries Gardens]] (''Jardins des Tuileries'') remain, preserving their wide central pathway, though the palace was burned down during the [[Paris Commune]], 1871.
Between the Tuileries gardens and the Champs Élysées extension a jumble of buildings remained on the site of [[Place de la Concorde]] until early in the reign of [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]], for whom the square was at first named. Then the garden axis could open through a grand gateway into the new royal square.
To the east, the Tuileries Palace faced an open square, the [[Place du Carrousel]]. There, by order of Napoleon, the [[Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel]] was centered on the palace (and so on the same axial line that was developing beyond the palace). Long-standing plans to link the entrance court of the "''[[Palais du Louvre|Vieux Louvre]]''", as the disused palace was called, with the court of the Tuileries, by sweeping away the intervening buildings, finally came to fruition in the early 19th century. Consequently, the older axis extending from the courtyard of the Louvre is slightly skewed to the rest of what has become the ''Axe historique,'' but the ''Arc du Carrousel'', at the fulcrum between the two, serves to disguise the discontinuity.
To the west, the completion of the [[Arc de Triomphe]] in 1836 on the [[Place de l'Étoile]] at the western end of the Champs Élysées formed the far point of this line of perspective, which now starts at the equestrian statue of [[Louis XIV]] placed by [[I.M. Pei]] adjacent to his [[Pyramide du Louvre]] in the ''Cour Napoléon'' of the [[Musée du Louvre]].
The axis was extended again westwards along the [[Avenue de la Grande Armée]], past the city boundary of Paris to [[La Défense]]. This was originally a large junction, named for a statue commemorating the defence of Paris in the [[Franco-Prussian War]].
In the 1950s, the area around ''La Défense'' was marked out to become a new business district, and high-rise office buildings were built along the avenue. The axis found itself extended yet again, with ambitious projects for the western extremity of the modern plaza.
It was not until the 1980s, under president [[François Mitterrand]], that a project was initiated, with a modern 20th century version of the ''Arc de Triomphe''. This is the work of [[Denmark|Danish]] architect [[Johann Otto von Spreckelsen]], ''La Grande Arche de la Fraternité'' (also known as simply ''La [[Grande Arche]]'' or ''L'Arche de la Défense''), a monument to humanity and humanitarian ideals rather than militaristic victories. It was inaugurated in 1989.
The network of railway lines and road tunnels beneath the elevated plaza of ''La Défense'' prevented the pillars supporting the arch from being exactly in line with the axis: it is slightly out of line, bending the axis should it be extended further to the west. From the roof of the ''Grande Arche'', a second axis can be seen: the [[Tour Montparnasse]] stands exactly behind the [[Eiffel Tower]]. The ''Seine-Arche'' project is extending the historical axis to the West through the city of [[Nanterre]], but with a slight curve.
{{Wide image|Paris Axe Historique.gif|1000px}}
==Gallery== <gallery perrow="5"> Champs-Elysées, vue de la Concorde à l'Etoile.jpg|The ''Axe historique'' looking west from the [[Place de la Concorde]] Axe-magistral.jpg|The ''Axe historique'' seen from the [[Tuileries Gardens]]. DefenseDusk.jpg|The ''Grande Arche'' seen from the ''Arc de Triomphe'' on the ''Axe historique''. VBRITTO-tuileries-vers-arc-2008.jpg|View from the Tuileries towards the ''Arc de Triomphe''. Arc De Triomphe from La Defense.jpg|The ''Arc de Triomphe'' from ''La Défense'' 5 km (3 mi) away, showing how precisely the axis is aligned. Axe-historique.jpg|From the roof of the ''Grande Arche'', past the skyscrapers of ''La Défense'', down the ''Axe historique''. </gallery>
==External links== {{Commons category|Axe historique}} {{Wikivoyage}} *[http://www.greatbuildings.com/buildings/La_Grande_Arche.html Entry] on greatbuildings.com
{{Visitor attractions in Paris|state=collapsed}}
